text: For me, the crucible was Clinton impeachment. There was lots of inaccurate reporting, but also things we decided were wrong that turned out to be right. ABC took lots of heat for the blue dress. Most of us decided it was a myth. It turned out to be true:
author: ktumulty

text: “Too good to check” is actually a joke, not a principle reporters follow. The other aphorism: The most miserable reporter is one who has a scoop that remains a scoop.
author: ktumulty

text: And flat-out wrong. OTOH, ABC took a lot of heat for reporting on a single source that there was a stained blue dress. Most media ended up deciding it was a myth. It turned out to be true: http://www.journalism.org/1998/10/20/the-blue-dress/ …
author: ktumulty

text: Not really a profit motive. More that reporters — myself included — get real pride from making the competition chase a scoop. During the Clinton impeachment saga, there were a lot of stories where subtle things made all the difference between a story being accurate 1/2

text: On a presidential trip, a credential gives you space to work from in the filing center, an ability to go to briefings, access to pool reports.
author: ktumulty

text: A Capitol credential also allows me to stand in the Speakers Lobby and ask questions of members as they go in and out of the chamber to vote. And it allows me to work from the Press Gallery, which can be crucial on deadline.
author: ktumulty

text: For instance, I have a Capitol Hill credential. That gives me a seat at the press table in a committee hearing room. It gives the C-SPAN cameraman an opportunity to put his camera in the room.
author: ktumulty

text: When people talk about "access journalism," they usually mean getting too close to sources. That is about relationships, not physical proximity, and can be done with or without a credential. A credential gets you into a bldg (or onto a trip, which new org pays cost of).
author: ktumulty

text: Opinion | Why I revealed that Tom Brokaw harassed me
author: ktumulty

text: Through security more quickly. Seats in the briefing room are assigned by news organization.
author: ktumulty

text: Lots of different kinds. Hill and various agencies issue their own credentials. Most WH reporters carry a “hard pass” that gets them 1/2
author: ktumulty

text: And finally (sorry yet that you asked?), a lot of the kind of “access” you are talking about happens on the phone or outside the building. Reporter presence w/in the security perimeter is pretty restricted — but crucial.
author: ktumulty

text: Please see my tweets on the difference between being credentialed and having “access.” Also my exchanges with @armandodkos on this.
author: ktumulty

text: Also, you don’t need credentials to get the kind of “access” you are talking about. They are only a means of getting through security in the building or on the trip.
author: ktumulty

text: Then think of it this way: Not a good precedent.

text: Credentials do not grant “access.” They grant the ability to observe and report, including when the president travels. Important to understand the difference.

text: Not the way it works. Credentials don’t equal access. They equal ability to observe and report, including when the president travels.
